title: browserify opts.basedir isn't global
body:
Is this expected?

I assumed that if you pass a `basedir` then you can require `./x` from anywhere and it'll work if `x` exists at the `basedir`. It doesn't seem to do at all for me. For me, it just effects the paths you pass to `browserify`.

Before: 

``` coffeescript
browserified = browserify './src/hello.coffee',
    extensions: ['.coffee']

browserified.transform coffeeify,
    global: true

browserified.bundle
    extensions: ['.coffee']
```

After: 

``` coffeescript
browserified = browserify './hello.coffee',
    extensions: ['.coffee']
    basedir: './src'

browserified.transform coffeeify,
    global: true

browserified.bundle
    extensions: ['.coffee']
```

(If `src` isn't removed from the entry file path then an error is thrown that `./src/hello.coffee` can't be found from `./src`)

---

browserify: `4.2.1`
node: `0.10.20`
npm: `1.3.11`
windows: `8.1`

title: browserify opts.insertGlobalVars does nothing

``` coffeescript
browserified = browserify entryFilePath,
    extensions: ['.coffee']
    insertGlobalVars:

browserified.transform coffeeify,
    global: true

browserified.bundle
    extensions: ['.coffee']
```

Then `x` doesn't exist. 

Any ideas?

---

browserify: `4.2.1`
node: `0.10.20`

title: Pass `debug` flag through to transform options.
body:
When using the debug option from either the command-line or module API, each transform stream's options will be modified to include `{ debug: true }`.

Likewise, false will be used if browserify is not running in debug mode. If a transform has specified its own debug option that value will be used instead.

I can see this is useful in a number of cases, but for me specifically it's to enable sourcemaps on glslify shaders when `--debug` is enabled.

Thanks!

title: Idea: ignoring duplicate b.require() / b.transform() calls?
body:
I have a use case where I pass around a browserify instance for multiple modules to apply their respective `transform()`s and `require()`s to, but I've run into a situation where the same require/transform ends up being applied multiple times.

To elaborate a bit on my specific case, let's say I have a project like this:

```
workshop
├── exercises
│   ├── 00
│   │   ├── bundler.js
│   │   ├── index.js
│   ├── 01
│   │   ├── bundler.js
│   │   ├── index.js
│   ├── 02
│   │   ├── bundler.js
│   │   └── index.js
│   └── common-bundler.js
└── index.js
```

And I want to allow each exercise to specify its own function (i.e., `bundler.js`) that accepts a browserify object and calls `require` and `transform` on it as necessary. For example, one of them might look like this:

``` js
module.exports = function (b) {
  require('../common-bundler')(b)
  b.transform(require.resolve('html-browserify'))
  b.require('some-module', { expose: 'beep-boop' })
}
```

As you might expect, there will be duplicate calls to `require` and `transform` here (especially when requiring `common-bundler.js`).

Does it make sense to have browserify deduplicate exactly-matching require and transform calls, or is there any conceivable case where it's useful to apply the same (exact) transform / require multiple times?

title: node_modules symlinks
body:
so, I've been using this pattern of symlinking a /lib folder into node_modules so that I can always require things local to a project without specifying long relative paths (e.g. avoiding `require('../../../../some-module')`).

however, regular browserify transforms don't get applied to any files included this way because moduleDeps doesn't consider them to be top level: https://github.com/substack/module-deps/blob/master/index.js#L171

this patch addresses the issue by resolving all symlinks with `fs.realpath` before handing off to moduleDeps.

although I've been able to work around this by using globalTransforms, they are much slower than the simple realpath check for projects with many dependencies.

title: Gulp transformations
Use absolute paths to calculate hash
body:
I have the problem that I have
- a bundle "a" that exports some modules
- these modules are required by another bundle "b"
- bundle "a" and bundle "b" are in different node_modules
- the uber-project is "node dedupe"d

In this case the relative paths to the module are different from bundle "a" and bundle "b", which results in bundle "b" not being able to resolve the required module.

Calculating the hashes based on the absolute paths solves that problem. It also keeps the side-effect that should two different versions of the same module be exported they will get a different hash as npm won't dedupe them.

This patch calculates the hash based on absolute file paths.

title: Return of require('querystring') does not match Node API
body: According to http://nodejs.org/api/querystring.html, the returned object should have `escape` and `unescape` methods. Instead, it has `encode` and `decode`, with a different API, in that they return objects instead of strings.

```
var paths = {
```

title: fix crash when numeric module names are passed as cli args
body:
If you pass a numeric module name to the browserify CLI in arguments such as ignore, exclude, require etc, it usually crashes. Came across this when trying to include the [66 module](https://www.npmjs.org/package/66).

I made sure optimist parses these arguments as strings, added aliases and removed concat calls that were no longer needed. Also added a test to prevent a regression.

title: package.json 'standalone' option
body:
I have the case where my module is named `peaks.js` BUT the `.` character is not used as a namespace.

To keep it simple, I thought of an extra browserify option, `standalone`, to match its  command line equivalent:

``` js
{
  "name": "peaks.js",
  "main": "src/main.js",
  "browserify": {
    "standalone": "peaks",
    "transforms": [
      "deamdify"
    ]
  }
}
```

This way running `browserify -s > peaks.js` would favour the `pkg.browserify.standalone` name instead of the `pkg.name` one.

Pretty much handy when you distribute the module as a library.

I think also to `browserify-cdn` where there is not much room (nor will) to add this kind of forced setting.

title: streams : wrong dependencies execution order
body:
With the following test.js file :

``` js
var stream = require('readable-stream');
console.log(stream.Transform.prototype.on);
```

In nodejs, I get the expected `[Function]` loggued.
I then use browserify :

``` sh
$ browserify --version
4.2.0
$ browserify test.js -o bundle.js -s bundle
```

In a browser (tested with Firefox 30 and Chromium 35), I get `undefined`.

In the generated bundle.js file, if I add a log for each interesting `inherits` call, I get :

```
Stream inherits EventEmitter
Writable inherits Stream
Duplex inherits Readable
Transform inherits Duplex
PassThrough inherits Transform
Readable inherits Stream          // <- too late !
```

The Readable class inherits Stream too late, and the other classes don't get its methods (like `on`).

noParse and streams?

title: Bundle callback does not handle errors on stream
body:
After upgrading from 3.x to 4.2 the `bundle` function no longer handles errors emitted on a transform's stream.

```

```

That error is thrown before the bundle callback is reached.

To reproduce: https://github.com/jnordberg/coffeeify/blob/master/test/error.js

title: Parsing error when json attribute is named "required"
body: Browserify throws an error ("Unexpected token :") when importing a JSON file containing a JSON property named "required". Unfortunately, in JSON schema the property "required" is an official keyword. Example: File "foo.json" contains the following JSON code: { "required": [] } File "bar.js" requires foo.json: var foo = require('./foo.json'); In this situation, Browserify fails to parse bar.js with the error message "Unexpected token :".

title: semicolon not added to the end of the generated file
body: I am in the odd situation of needing to concatenate the result of browserify with some other scripts. The file generated by browserify is a self-executing anonymous function, but it doesn't have a semicolon at the end. In my case, it is followed by another parentheses wrapped self executing anonymous function. This causes an "uncaught object" error.

title: Recognize when a module will never be required
body:
Based on https://github.com/SheetJS/js-xlsx/issues/76 , the issue reduces to the following:

Suppose you had the script:

```
var bar = {};
if(typeof bar === undefined) bar = require('./baz');
```

It should be pretty clear that the require will never be called.  However, browserify tries to find the `./baz` script anyway.  

I am aware that it's not the greatest structure (in the original case, it was generated by concatenating two scripts). It would seem that the require call will never be run.  Is this expected behavior?  Is there a way to indicate that browserify should not try to inline the call?

title: "browser" field in package.json confusion
body:
I am trying to use the `browser` field in my module to achieve the following behaviour, however it does not work as I would have expected.

Here is a bare bones example of what I am trying to achieve:
## Inside the depending app:

`index.js`

``` js
require('my-dep/a')
```
## Inside the module dependency

`node_modules/my-dep/package.json`

``` json
{
  "name": "my-dep",
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "browser": {
    "./a.js": "./b.js"
  }
}
```

Running the following command puts the contents of `a.js` into the browserify'd bundle and _not_ `b.js`:

```
browserify index.js > build.js
```

I would have expected this to work. I don't know if it is my mistake, or if it is a bug with the implementation of the `browser` field…

This use case of reaching directly for a file in a dependency (rather than resolving the main file) seems to not be covered. Is this intentional, or just not implemented yet?

cc/ @defunctzombie as I think this might have something to do with `browser-resolve`.

title: Difficulty with "browser" field in package.json
body:
Maybe I'm not understanding how the "browser" field works in `package.json`. I would like to be able to say "I have a `main` for when this module is required from node, and I have a `browser` for when this module is required from browserify." However, I'm running into an error:

**package.json**

``` json
{
    "main": "main.js",
    "browser": "built.js"
}
```

**main.js**

``` js
console.log('main');
```

**Trying to run browserify**

```
$ browserify main.js 
Error: module "/private/tmp/browserify-demo/built.js" not found from "/"
    at notFound (/Users/nick.heiner/.npm-global/lib/node_modules/browserify/index.js:812:15)
    at /Users/nick.heiner/.npm-global/lib/node_modules/browserify/index.js:762:23
    at /Users/nick.heiner/.npm-global/lib/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/browser-resolve/index.js:185:24

    at Object.oncomplete (fs.js:107:15)
```

It looks like this happens because of the following in `browser-resolve`:

``` js
            // if browser field is a string
            // then it just replaces the main entry point
            if (typeof info.browser === 'string') {
                var key = path.resolve(cur_path, info.main || 'index.js');
                shims[key] = path.resolve(cur_path, info.browser);
                return cb(null, shims);
            }
```

Am I misusing the `browser` field? Or is this supposed to work?

title: Node API help is lacking, difficult to use
Browserify-shim cannot find shimmed module
body:
I cannot seem to Browserify the packages knockout and knockout-projections.

To illustrate the problem I have created a repository:  [brianmhunt/bshim-ko-testcase](/brianmhunt/bshim-ko-testcase) — The vendor packages in the repository have been stripped of irrelevant code to illustrate the problem.

I first raised this as thlorenz/browserify-shim#67 but @thlorenz [mentioned he was unable to root out the issue](https://github.com/thlorenz/browserify-shim/issues/67#issuecomment-46766541) and he suggested I raise it here. He also noted that removing the shim was not necessary.

@mikekidder [commented](https://github.com/thlorenz/browserify-shim/issues/46#issuecomment-46767699) that he has narrowed the issue to a [`rename` call](https://github.com/thlorenz/browserify-shim/blob/master/index.js#L184) in browserify-shim. He also noted that the issue does not occur with  browserify-shim 3.2.2 (and browserify 3.46.2, by peer-dependency).

I have since removed the browserify-shim dependency in the test repository above, but the issue still occurs, meaning the problem must with browserify itself.

Cheers.

title: idea: cache module-deps in fs
body:
Instead of recomputing module deps for `node_modules` all the time, make use of the fact that `module@version` will always produce the same module-deps output (you can't npm publish over an existing version) and cache somewhere in the file system, like `~/.browserify/cache/module/version.json`.

module-deps already takes a `{ cache: ... }` argument, so I guess this is best added into browserify directly? Another option would be to add a `{ depsResolver: ... }` option to browserify and pass in a module that wraps module-deps with the added caching layer.

What do you think is the best way to approach this?

title: idea: pull out !node logic
body:
Create a module like `commonjsify` that is like browserify would have been if it only emulated a commonjs environment. Or call it `npmify`. No implicit `Buffer`, `process` etc. Basically only the module system, transforms and all the other !node things.

Then, refactor browserify to use that module and add all the node stuff.

I've come to this idea working with component and liking that it's not emulating an environment but rather leaving you with an empty slate, without any (node) compatibility features.

Afaik browserify is already going that direction, recommending to require node core modules from npm with explicit versioning, instead of relying on the versions bundled with browserify.

title: Can't figure out how to ignore a Package
body:
I can't figure out how to get ignore to work on a package.
## Case 1

With this minimal test case js file:

`coffee.js`

``` javascript
module.exports = require("coffee-script");
```

Running browserify with these arguments:

``` bash
browserify coffee.js -i coffee-script > test.js
```

I get the following error:

`Error: module "coffee-script" not found from "/home/daniel/apps/coffee.js"`

I would expect `coffee-script` to be ignored and replaced with an empty exports.
## Case 2 (With coffee-script installed in node-modules)

``` bash
browserify coffee.js -i coffee-script > test.js
```

Works, but test.js is > 300k because it includes coffee-script
## Case 3 (also using `--noparse`)

``` bash
browserify coffee.js -i coffee-script --no-parse coffee-script > test.js
```

Appears to be correct, but why do I also need `--no-parse` if I have `-i` ?

title: `noParse` in package.json of dependency
body:
I have a module—call it module "A"—that npm-depends on jQuery. I'd like to specify that jQuery not be parsed whenever "A" is included in a Browserify bundle. "A" is required a lot in my application's AST, so it would be a huge savings to have "A"'s jQuery not parsed whenever "A" is looked up by `module-deps`. How can I make this happen?

I've tried adding 

```
"browserify": {
  "noParse": [ "node_modules/jquery/dist/jquery" ]
}
```

to "A"'s `package.json`, but it doesn't seem to improve performance. (I've tried stepping through bundling runs but I'm very new to the codebase and am not quickly figuring out the precise flow). Based on my understanding so far, though, there doesn't seem to be a way to add the `noParse` to `browserify`'s `opts`, because `noParse` there has to be absolute.

body:
In regards to omsmith/browserify-ngannotate#3

Would it make sense to add an error listener globally to transform streams in browserify to report the filename passed in to the transform?

I'm not positive how appropriate it is, but it also seems off doing it within every transform.

Thoughts?

Using Browserify and RequireJS on the same page?
body:
So i've come across an interesting use case where i'm using Browserify to bundle all of my assets together in a project, but a large external (external to the project) module needs to be loaded in when a certain in-app window is accessed. (It's a video player module made up of three scripts that get pulled in asynchronously when required).

At the moment i'm getting all kinds of errors from `uncalled object` errors if the requireJS module is loaded in _before_ the Browserified app.js file, to `cannot find module` errors if loaded in _after_ the Browserified code.

Is there anyway i can get Browserify and RequireJS to play nicely on the same page? I'm losing my mind!

title: Requiring a jade from a module in node_modules/ doesn't work as expected
body:
I have asked on SO too: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/23908146/browserify-jadeify-requiring-a-jade-from-a-module-inside-node-modules-strang

**Problem**

I'm requiring a jade in my class. All is working fine if I put my modules into a libs folder (outside node_moduleS) but when I move into node_modules, the jadeify transform, is never called on my **require('./views/index.jade')**. I have debugged the source of jadeify to verify that this require() doesn't pass through it.

**index.jade**

```
p= data.name
p
  | console.log("urzuleibailadu")
```

**child module**

```
function Child () {
  console.log('Dirname: ' + __dirname);
  Child.super_(this);
  console.log('Called new child()');
  this.pages = {};
  this.settings = {
    templates: {
      //index: ''
      index: require('./views/index.jade')
    }
  };
}
```

This is the project structure (libs/child and node_module/child contains the very same files):

```
- browserify
-- libs
--- child
---- views
----- index.jade
---- index.js
-- node_modules
--- child
---- views
----- index.jade
---- index.js
-- main.js
```

With this edit, in **main.js** all is working fine:

```
Child = require('./libs/child')
```

This, brokes all, causing **jade** being parsed as js (browser throws data is undefined, from `p= data.name` ).

```
Child = require('child')
```

Any ideas? Many thanks.

title: Problems with arrays + objects on the command line API
body:
Using browserify version 4.1.5.

When invoked like this:

`$ browserify -t [ transform --option val ] main.js > bundle.js`

The transform gets this object:

`{"_":[],"option":"val"}`

So far so good. But should that "_" property be there? Anyway, when invoked like this:

`$ browserify -t [ transform --option '["val"]' ] main.js > bundle.js`

The transform gets this object:

`{"_":[],"option":{"_":["val"]}}`

So close! I'm not sure what's happening here but it seems like it's _trying_ to parse the JSON, but somehow tripping up. The array does get parsed, it's just hidden inside an object. Different variations of the same happen with different kinds of quoting (and no quotes at all) in the shell invocation.

title: convention for using package.json to hint at the JavaScript standard required
prototype.transform should accept transform(t, opts);

https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/master/index.js#L355 should be `opts = t_;` I think?

Sorry this isn't a PR, will send one if I have a opportunity.

title: sourceMappingURL directive can fail if a bundled module specifies the directive
body:
If a bundled module has a `sourceMappingURL` directive, browserify will leave it intact, which appears to be worthless or harmful towards getting source maps to work properly in browsers.

Ideally, when browserify is generating source maps it would detect `sourceMappingURL` directives in bundled modules and include the contents of the targeted source maps in the bundle's source map. At very least, the directives should be removed during bundling to prevent possible conflicts.

The same issue is present in webpack, so I will refer to the bug report there rather than duplicate it: https://github.com/webpack/webpack/issues/273

The only difference between browserify and webpack with this issue is that browserify does not use the deprecated `//@` form of the directive, so it will only see the issue of duplicate `sourceMappingURL` directives when the bundled module has a directive in the form `//# sourceMappingURL=...`.

title: Fix a typo for the 'global-transform' switch in the readme.
Allow passing streams to module pack pipeline
tiny spelling fix in changelog
Document how to avoid relative paths hell
body:
The `paths` option, that  forwards to https://github.com/defunctzombie/node-browser-resolve is not documented here

In my browserify app, for my private JS code, I don't want to use relative paths because it's annoying when you move some code from one place to another to have to update all the relative paths.
See http://stackoverflow.com/a/23608416/82609

It seems the paths option permits to make available your own js files like normal node modules.
As far as I have seen it works pretty fine and the browserify app is being build without using relative paths.

The problem is that in my paths folders I have JSX React files that must be compiled to JS before being integrated by browserify.
It seems browserify doesn't transform these files unless I reference them with their relative paths.
I don't know if this is a bug or an intended behavior.
I think it could be nice, for each path, to specify if we want it to be transformed by browserify or not.
Currently my browserify bundle contains raw uncompiled JSX code, and it breaks at runtime.

Until now I did not find any clear solution on how to handle the `relative paths everywhere` problem. I think it's a pretty common problem that can be really annoying on large code base when refactoring. It's also solved easily with requirejs so I guess it would be nice to document how to do it with browserify.

title: `e.code == 'MODULE_NOT_FOUND'`
body:
1. Normally, browserify will error out when it cannot find a module, but it (correctly) doesn't fail when the require is dynamic.
2. Many modules attempt to load optional modules, catching `e.code == 'MODULE_NOT_FOUND'` to fallback gracefully to something else.
3. Browserify's error does not include `e.code = 'MODULE_NOT_FOUND` (at least in chrome 34)

Proof at http://bl.ocks.org/jbenet/63bdbb52294c9858a959

I'm currently catching such an error using:

``` js
function (err) {
  return err.code == 'MODULE_NOT_FOUND' // node
    || err.toString().match(/Cannot find module/); //browserify
}
```

But, it would be great if Browserify included the code, as [lots of people use it](https://github.com/search?q=.code+%3D%3D+MODULE_NOT_FOUND&type=Code&ref=searchresults). Happy to PR, but not sure where the error is coming from. So far I see: https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/df8d3b5a6766a85393a57c10ed49c7582e77e81c/index.js#L738 (potentially patch it in there?)

Is the error coming from `resolve` (https://github.com/substack/node-resolve/blob/591e359faf5e2eb9c7f5cc86c9ac389c43d961e8/lib/sync.js#L32)? Doesn't seem to have the " from ... " part.

title: Defining global variable
body:
I'm using SpineJS (which exports a commonjs module) and it should be available globally as I use it everywhere, but It seems like as I have to do "Spine = require('spine')" on every file that uses Spine.

There is anyway where I define Spine once and never more (like defined globally)?

PS: I give Spine as an example, but I believe that it should be the same process with any other library.
